questions.stem:
A workflow is defined as following:

If Task B failed during a job run, which statement is correct?

options.label: Task A completed successfully. Some of Task B and Task C’s operations may be completed successfully.
Task A completed successfully. Task B and Task C’s operations failed completely.
Both Task A and Task C are completed successfully. Task B’s operations failed completely.
Both Task A and Task C completed successfully. Some of Task B’s operations may have been completed successfully.

rationales: Task C will complete as it is not dependent on Task B. See “Task Management.”
Task C will complete as it is not dependent on Task B. See “Task Management.”
Some of Task B’s operations may be completed successfully. See “Task Management.”
Both Task A and Task C completed successfully. Some of Task B’s operations may have been completed successfully. See “Task Management.”

questions.stem: Given the following workflow definition, what will happen if Task A is successful and Task B fails? Assuming Task C’s data operation can be generated without the result of B.

options.label: Operations in Task A and C are completely successful. Some operations in Task B may be successful.
Operations in Task A are completely successful. Some operations in Task B and C may be successful.
Operations in Task A are completely successful. Operations in Task B failed completely. Task C is not started.
Operations in Task A are completely successful. Some operations in Task B may be successful. Task C is not started.

rationales: Task C is not started. See Module 5, “Testing and Deployment.”
Task C is not started. See Module 5, “Testing and Deployment.”
Some operations in Task B may be successful. See Module 5, “Testing and Deployment.”
C depends on B so if B fails C will not get executed. See Module 5, “Testing and Deployment.”
